dataset.title: PEL'S FISHING OWL Scotopelia peli GROUND SURVEY OF THE OLIFANTS RIVER, KRUGER NATIONAL PARK 2007-2010

abstract.para:
A ground-based survey of Pel's Fishing Owl Scotopelia peli along the Olifants River in the Kruger National Park was conducted from the 22nd-25th of June 2008 by two teams of observers from SAN-Parks, staff and volunteers from EWT-BoPWG.
This ground survey was the second to be conducted for the Pel's Fishing Owl and other selected species occurring along the Olifants River in the Kruger National Park since the detailed surveys conducted by Keith Begg (unpubl. data) in the early 1990's. It was preceded by a similar survey being conducted over the corresponding week in 2007 and forms part of the registered research project focused on this species within the Kruger National Park.

intellectualRights.para: This data may not be shared generally. Please get permisiion from Andre Botha if you would like to use this data

section.title: Survey methods
section.para: The ground survey was conducted over a period of four days by two separate teams (see acknowledgements), with preference being given to the early morning, from shortly after sunrise until the survey was completed for the day. Each team consisted of 6 observers with 3 observers on the northern- and 3 on the southern bank of the river walking downstream and recording what they see.Only avifauna was recorded once it/they had flown passed in a westerly direction thus avoiding duplication. However, due to the high levels of the river and the inaccessibility of certain sites on the southern bank in the western half of the survey area, very little physical coverage of the southern bank in this area could be obtained. It is likely that some owls may have been missed due to this limitation.The teams walked along the riverbank, scouring suitable looking trees for the presence (flushed birds or confirmed sightings) or signs of Pel's Fishing Owl being present. The Eastern team was divided into two to cover both the northern and southern banks of the river walking in a straight line at times extending to approximately 50-150 metres from the river banks on both sides depending on the extent of riparian vegetation. Tributaries with suitable vegetation were also covered for at least 100-500m from the main river depending on the nature of the vegetation. Regular radio contact was maintained between the teams and all relevant information was recorded on a CyberTracker device or Dictaphone carried by each team leader. Standard information recorded for all sightings or signs of Pel's Fishing Owl were the following:
4. Species of tree/s (if relevant) and description of site
5. Nature of sighting or signs (feathers, faeces, prey remains, roost, potential nesting site)

In addition to Pel's Fishing Owl, sightings of other waterbirds, raptors and hippopotamus were also recorded along the survey area. All relevant species of birds flying or moving past the teams in an easterly direction were recorded. No birds flying to the east or ahead of the direction of movement of the teams were recorded to prevent potential double counts. Field rangers accompanying the teams also took the opportunity of recording any sightings and spoor of certain game species, the presence of alien vegetation and other information

description.para:
The survey was conducted in the riparian vegetation along the Olifants River in the central area of the Kruger National Park, stretching from the western boundary fence of the Park, known as Mamba Picket (24"02"025'S 031"12"545'E) to the eastern boundary fence beyond Bangu Gorge (23"57"651'S 031"52"850'E), a distance of approximately 93km along the river.
The riparian vegetation in this area is dominated by tree species such as Jackalberry Diospyros mespiliformis, Natal Mahogany Trichilia emetica, Sycamore Fig Ficus sycamorus, Anatree Acacia albida and Weeping Boer-bean Schotia brachypetala. Shrubby vegetation of the lower stratum consists mainly of species such as Red Spike-thorn Maytenus senegalensis and Large Fever Berry Croton megalobotrys spp. Vegetation suited to the requirements of Pel's Fishing Owl occurs sporadically along the course of the river.

samplingDescription.para: Each team consisted of 6 observers with 3 observers on the northern- and 3 on the southern bank of the river walking downstream and recording what they see.
